awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Closed-loop control of engineered metabolism using biosensors and optogenetics
awd_abstract_narration:
Biotechnology can produce a vast number of valuable products from renewable sources. One barrier to making these products economically is our inability to easily redirect cellular metabolism to maximize production. New technologies to significantly improve our ability to control engineered microorganisms, using light and biological sensors, will be developed. This strategy will enable feed-back controls, in which light signals used to fine-tune enzyme concentrations are informed by fluorescence signals from biosensors in real time.  The approach will allow the development of entirely new technologies to control, optimize, and operate fermentations, as well as improve our basic understanding of how enzyme concentrations affect product formation. The results of this project will be incorporated into several courses currently taught. Outreach activities to two organizations with which the PI has been involved previously (Hispanics Inspiring Student's Performance and Achievement, and Society for the Advancement of Chicano/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science) will promote STEM-related careers among under-represented groups and encourage their participation in related research.
 
The objective of this project is to develop a closed-loop control system for metabolic engineering using biosensors and optogenetics. Three components will be integrated in the same yeast strain: (i) a metabolic pathway to produce a chemical of interest; (ii) a biosensor to monitor the activity of said pathway; and (iii) optogenetic tools to control enzyme expression levels. This will allow fine-tuning of enzyme concentrations using light. These three components have been developed in separate yeast strains in the PI's lab. The first objective is to integrate all three components in a single yeast strain. Success will be demonstrated by the production of branched chain alcohols. The second objective is to adapt an existing optogenetic tool sensitive to red and infrared light to work orthogonally with the existing blue light system. This technology will open the door to new strategies to operate and optimize fermentations, such as by using periodic light pulses with feedback controls, providing unprecedented capabilities for operating, optimizing, and automating fermentations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Similar to the way a thermostat controls the temperature of a house, bioreactors used for the biomanufacturing of fuels, chemicals, or drugs use controls for temperature, pH, oxygenation, cell density, and volume to keep these parameters at optimal operation conditions. However, there are currently no such "thermostats" available to monitor and control in real time the metabolic processes that occur inside the microorganisms growing and producing inside bioreactors. These "metabolic thermostats", in combination with current extracellular controls (e.g., for temperature, pH, etc.) would significantly improve the efficiency, productivity, and reproducibility of biomanufacturing processes. 

This project achieved the development of the basic components required to build "metabolic thermostats": The first components are optogenetic actuators that enable the control of biological processes with light. Actuators are equivalent to the electrical circuits that turn on or off the heating or cooling systems in a room controlled with a thermostat. In this case, however, light-responsive proteins are used to turn gene expression on or off with light, thereby controlling metabolic pathways with light. These controls where demonstrated to able to balance metabolic pathways for cell growth and chemical production, as the competition between cell replication and biosynthetic pathways is a common challenge in biomanufacturing processes. Using light, instead of chemical inducers, has several advantages, including light’s tunability, reversibility, low side effects, and ease with which it can interface with computers (a field called cybergenetics). In this project, optogenetic controls of gene expression were demonstrated for the two main workhorses in microbial biomanufacturing: the baker's yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, and non-pathogenic Escherichia coli.

The second components of "metabolic thermostats" are genetically encoded biosensors that can monitor the metabolic state of the cell by emitting an easy measurable signal. In this project, such biosensors were developed for the biosynthesis of two branched-chain heavy alcohols (BCHAs), isobutanol and isopentanol, in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. These BCHAs are advanced biofuels that can be used as drop-in fuel substitutes for gasoline or upgraded to jet fuel. They can also be converted to produce isobutene or isopentene, two petrochemicals used in the production of polymers. The genetically encoded biosensors developed monitor the biosynthesis of isobutanol or isopentanol by emitting fluorescent signals proportional to the metabolic activity of these pathways. These biosensors were used to isolate the most productive strains and improve metabolic enzymes. 

These two components, optogenetic actuators and genetically encoded biosensors for BCHA production, have been demonstrated to be simultaneously functional in the same cell, enabling the monitoring of BCHA production in optogenetically controlled strains. This forms the basis for the technological development of closed-loop controls of metabolism, or "metabolic thermostats". Future efforts will focus on reducing the delays associated with actuation and biosensing in order to realize and optimize closed-loop controls of metabolism. This technology will have significant impact in the fields of metabolic engineering, optogenetics, cybergentics, fermentation technology, and biomanufacturing. It promises to realize closed-loop control of bioprocesses, which are foundational to the great success that the chemical industry has enjoyed for over a century.

This project has also made impact in the education and training of several students in STEM, including students from traditionally underrepresented groups. The project has directly benefitted the lab training of 20 undergraduate students, 16 graduate students, and 5 postdoctoral trainees. In addition, the methods and results obtained from this research have been taught in the three undergraduate courses taught by the PI (Introduction to Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, Chemical Reaction Engineering, and Fundamentals of Biofuels). The research project has also been instrumental in disseminating scientific literacy to high school students from disadvantaged communities of Trenton, NJ.
